stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the session polishing the Western-themed level, now officially called “Grand Sand Badland.”  Work centers on saloon swinging doors, the Boshi quick-draw duel, minor visual glitches, and small memory optimizations as the stage nears completion.

development_findings.summary: The Western level is nearly finished; remaining tasks are fixing floating train tracks, animating wheels, adding smoke/SFX, installing a Chain Chomp, finishing bartender hat growth, and final star names.
development_findings.quote: “We got a few things left to finish up… train tracks, Chain Chomp, wheels, some sound, some smoke, bartender’s hat.”

development_findings.summary: Level name finalized as “Grand Sand Badland.”
development_findings.quote: “Yes, I said Grand Sand Badland. That is likely going to be the final name.”

development_findings.summary: A 3-2-1 visual & audio countdown was added to the Boshi quick-draw duel after chat feedback; timing tweaked from 48 → 52 frames for fairness.
development_findings.quote: “You definitely need more time before ‘fire’ … alright, I’ll try a 3-2-1.”

development_findings.summary: Implemented swinging saloon doors with physics, collision, friction, and camera framing; corrected rotation bug caused by using faceAngle instead of angleToMario.
development_findings.quote: “It was all because I used face angle instead of angle-to-Mario.”

development_findings.summary: Bartender Koopa’s hat now grows ~10 units after each star to create a running gag; default size reduced so growth is noticeable.
development_findings.quote: “Maybe funnier if it starts a little crazier and gets a little crazier in the end.”

development_findings.summary: Boshi’s voice is pitched lower via a new per-dialogue pitch system; Kaze refactored the audio engine to remove duplicate code and make pitching ‘almost free.’
development_findings.quote: “We implemented this free of cost… now Boshi’s pitch has been lowered.”

development_findings.summary: Save-state-detecting Yoshi rap dialogues were rewritten (with community help) for better flow; Kaze integrated the updated text banks.
development_findings.quote: “Alright, now that we have B-Turk’s updated dialogues in here… these pros surely go hard.”

development_findings.summary: Memory is tight in Grand Sand Badland; new characters or minigames (e.g., horseshoe-throwing Hammer Bro) were cut; Wiggler & Chain Chomp moved to object-specific banks.
development_findings.quote: “We’re kind of out of memory on this level… don’t really want to add new characters if we can prevent that.”

development_findings.summary: Sauraen is working on a lighter F3DEX microcode to relieve RTYI’s current RSP bottleneck.
development_findings.quote: “RTYI is actually RSP bottlenecked… Sauraen’s new F3DEX3 should help.”

context_findings.summary: Kaze reviews criticism objectively but blocks users who spam or ping needlessly.
context_findings.quote: “Always look at criticism very objectively… if you are going to be annoying, I will block you.”

context_findings.summary: He felt ill pre-stream but perked up once coding, attributing it to pressure.
context_findings.quote: “God, I felt like shit before the stream started but now I’m feeling fine.”

context_findings.summary: Philosophy: code should be ‘free of cost’ unless actively used, and solutions should address real problems, not vice-versa.
context_findings.quote: “Every time you program something, you want it to be free of cost if you’re not using that part of code.”

context_findings.summary: Avoids self-inserts in his games, calling them ‘cringe.’
context_findings.quote: “I don’t put myself in my games. I think self-inserts is a little cringe.”

context_findings.summary: Works at a commercial game studio using Unreal Engine; upgraded his 2017 PC for that job.
Pays a shorts editor $270 per year; joked about trading a PC purchase against owed level-editing payments to Lilaa.

biobak.summary: Started re-working Course 11 visuals; showed before/after container texture demonstrating improved depth and weathering.
biobak.quote: “He just started reworking Course 11 and this already looks insane.”

badub.summary: Will compose completely custom music for the Boshi showdown instead of recycling existing tracks.
badub.quote: “I’m planning to have a completely custom music here… something like a proper [western tune].”

zeina.summary: Currently producing textures for in-level signs.
zeina.quote: “Yeah, not all the signs are there. Zeno’s making the textures.”

key_stories.title: Taming the Saloon Doors
key_stories.summary: The swinging doors initially rotated randomly and shoved Mario back into the warp.  After extensive debugging, Kaze discovered he was referencing the object’s face angle instead of its angle-to-Mario.
key_stories.challenge: Doors spun in the wrong direction and behaved inconsistently when pushed or punched.
key_stories.process: Added debug prints, rewrote rotation math several times, inverted signs, and finally replaced faceAngle with angleToMario.
key_stories.outcome: Doors now swing correctly, have proper friction, and fit a resized entrance.
key_stories.key_quote: “It was all because I used face angle instead of angle-to-Mario.”

key_stories.title: Giving Boshi a Deeper Voice
key_stories.summary: Kaze wanted Boshi to sound gruffer than regular Yoshi. The legacy sound-bank pitch code was inefficient, so he refactored the audio engine.
key_stories.challenge: Lower Boshi’s pitch without incurring per-frame CPU cost and without breaking other sounds.
key_stories.process: Audited duplicate pitch code, removed the old ‘soundBankPitch’ path, added per-dialogue pitch field, and tested with extreme values.
key_stories.outcome: Boshi’s voice is now subtly deeper; engine gained a cheap, flexible pitching feature.
key_stories.key_quote: “We implemented this free of cost… now Boshi’s pitch has been lowered.”

key_stories.title: Memory Budget vs. Feature Creep
key_stories.summary: Chat suggested adding a horseshoe-throwing Hammer Bro minigame, but Kaze declined.
key_stories.challenge: Western level is already hitting memory limits.
key_stories.process: Checked current bank usage; noted out-of-memory warnings; decided to move Wiggler and Chain Chomp to object-specific banks and avoid new NPCs.
key_stories.outcome: Minigame cut, memory reserved for essential objects and VFX.
key_stories.key_quote: “We’re kind of out of memory in this level, so I don’t really want to add new characters if we can prevent that.”

key_stories.title: Community-Written Anti-Savestate Raps
key_stories.summary: Viewer B-Turk rewrote the anti-savestate Yoshi rap lines; Kaze mass-edited the text bank to maintain 8-line formatting and rhythmic flow.
key_stories.challenge: Original rhymes were clunky; needed consistent syllable counts.
key_stories.process: Reviewed each of 17 dialogues on-stream, adjusted lines, and preserved formatting to avoid compile errors.
key_stories.outcome: Funnier, tighter raps now appear when the game detects savestate abuse.

open_questions.context: Kaze listed train wheels, tracks, VFX and audio as ‘still left to finish.’
questions: What technical method will animate the wheels without new memory banks?
Any performance concerns with smoke particle effects on N64 hardware?
Who is responsible for train sound design—Badub or someone else?

open_questions.context: Plan to move Wiggler & Chain Chomp allocs to an object-specific bank to free memory.
questions: Has the object-bank refactor been completed?
Will Chain Chomp reuse existing animations or require new ones?
Any fallback if memory savings are insufficient?

open_questions.context: Sauraen is rewriting microcode to lower RSP load.
questions: What measurable performance gain is expected?
Will this require re-exporting level geometry?
Timeline for merging into RTYI branch?

open_questions.context: Kaze wants a bespoke duel track.
questions: What style or instrumentation is Badub aiming for?
How will memory/sequence size be balanced?
Will there be dynamic layering during the countdown?

open_questions.context: Kaze said multiplayer ‘might still do it, but I haven’t thought about it.’
questions: What technical blockers remain for split-screen or alternating play?
Is the idea scoped for release or post-launch?
Would multiplayer exacerbate current performance bottlenecks?
